p.s: In his speech Boris Johnson tries to bring his audience to acting against climate change, while using the fear of letting future generations suffer as a motivation.
He starts off by comparing the climate change to a scenario in a James Bond movie (l. 6).
Thus he is also indirectly comparing his audience to a well known hero-like character.
He says how they can either act and be like the hero or fail and let future generations down.
These two points are used to pressure and motivate the people to acting against climate change.
He also explains what he consideresconsiders as acting against climate change, saying that promises they made were nothing but blah, blah, blah, to coin a phrase (l. 13).
This might be an allusion to a speech by climate activist Gretha Thunberg, who also used the phrase blah, blah, blah in a similar context.
Johnson goes on by naming the things they can change but are simply lacking the will to do so (l. 14).
The lacking funds are an excuse and it is their responsibility to find them (l. 19).
This makes his audience feel guilty for not taking action.
For almost three following paragraphs he brings his audience to thinking about how the future generations are going to be affected.
He stresses the importance of acting right now through a metaphor.
We mustn't fluff our lines or miss our cue(l. 40).
This also implies that they are forced to act now, as it is their turn.
During his speech, he uses a lot of inclusive language saying how the children who will judge us, are children not yet born (l. 38) and that they will not forgive us (l. 40).
This strenghensstrengthens the guilt and pressure that the audience feels.
At the end of his speech he brings back the comparison to James Bond he did earlier, saying that they have the chance to be like that hero and start acting against climate change (l. 49f) right now.
